Bug.Summery: [consistency] CoolBar DragDetect differences

Lines.Line: - run the ControlExample, select the CoolBar tab
- listen for DragDetect
- drag a CoolItem within the example CoolBar and note that no DragDetect is
fired, so this is inconsistent with the behaviour that I assumed to be correct
above and hence with the other platforms
- however, try to drag a CoolItem in the example CoolBar by using the correct
motif drag trigger (either middle mouse button or a mouse chord) and note that
DragDetect IS fired in this case, but the CoolItem will not become draggable
since this isn't the trigger that the control wants
- so the platform trigger for DragDetect is being respected here, but in this
case it doesn't match the semantics of the emulated widget, which uses button 1
for dragging
DragDetect is intended to indicate that drag & drop operation should start,
not that a cool item has been dragged. However, there seems to be a platform
difference.
If the meaning of DragDetect is no different for CoolBar than for other
widgets, then this is working correctly. It's unfortunate that the trigger for
dragging a CoolItem matches the usual drag trigger on some platforms but not on
others (ie.- motif), because as a result there are probably clients that are
hooking drag detect with the assumption that it behaves like the preamble from
comment 0, and are failing on motif as a result of this not being true.

Bug.WithStack:
preamble: Testing CoolBar first on win32 and gtk, it seems that DragDetect is fired whenever a CoolItem is dragged, but it is NOT fired if a drag is initiated on a part of a CoolBar that is not a gripper. I'm therefore assuming that the intent of DragDetect for CoolBars is to notify listeners precisely whenever a CoolItem drag begins.
steps for motif: - run the ControlExample, select the CoolBar tab - listen for DragDetect - drag a CoolItem within the example CoolBar and note that no DragDetect is fired, so this is inconsistent with the behaviour that I assumed to be correct above and hence with the other platforms - however, try to drag a CoolItem in the example CoolBar by using the correct motif drag trigger (either middle mouse button or a mouse chord) and note that DragDetect IS fired in this case, but the CoolItem will not become draggable since this isn't the trigger that the control wants - so the platform trigger for DragDetect is being respected here, but in this case it doesn't match the semantics of the emulated widget, which uses button 1 for dragging DragDetect is intended to indicate that drag & drop operation should start, not that a cool item has been dragged. However, there seems to be a platform difference. If the meaning of DragDetect is no different for CoolBar than for other widgets, then this is working correctly. It's unfortunate that the trigger for dragging a CoolItem matches the usual drag trigger on some platforms but not on others (ie.- motif), because as a result there are probably clients that are hooking drag detect with the assumption that it behaves like the preamble from comment 0, and are failing on motif as a result of this not being true.
There is a platform difference that still needs to be addressed. Grant to prioritize. Work is discontinued on SWT's Motif port. Closing report, platform is discontinued.
Bug.WithOutStack:
preamble: Testing CoolBar first on win32 and gtk, it seems that DragDetect is fired whenever a CoolItem is dragged, but it is NOT fired if a drag is initiated on a part of a CoolBar that is not a gripper. I'm therefore assuming that the intent of DragDetect for CoolBars is to notify listeners precisely whenever a CoolItem drag begins.
steps for motif: - run the ControlExample, select the CoolBar tab - listen for DragDetect - drag a CoolItem within the example CoolBar and note that no DragDetect is fired, so this is inconsistent with the behaviour that I assumed to be correct above and hence with the other platforms - however, try to drag a CoolItem in the example CoolBar by using the correct motif drag trigger (either middle mouse button or a mouse chord) and note that DragDetect IS fired in this case, but the CoolItem will not become draggable since this isn't the trigger that the control wants - so the platform trigger for DragDetect is being respected here, but in this case it doesn't match the semantics of the emulated widget, which uses button 1 for dragging DragDetect is intended to indicate that drag & drop operation should start, not that a cool item has been dragged. However, there seems to be a platform difference. If the meaning of DragDetect is no different for CoolBar than for other widgets, then this is working correctly. It's unfortunate that the trigger for dragging a CoolItem matches the usual drag trigger on some platforms but not on others (ie.- motif), because as a result there are probably clients that are hooking drag detect with the assumption that it behaves like the preamble from comment 0, and are failing on motif as a result of this not being true.
There is a platform difference that still needs to be addressed. Grant to prioritize. Work is discontinued on SWT's Motif port. Closing report, platform is discontinued.

Bug.Summery: [consistency] List fires second selection on default selection

Lines.Line: - run the ControlExample, go to the List tab
- listen for Selection and Default Selection
- double click an item in the example List on the page
-> on gtk you'll get Selection - Selection - Default Selection
-> on all other platforms you'll get Selection - Default Selection
Probably true in Tree and Table as well. I tried to work around this once.
GTK is actually issuing two events. The only way to fix this is to remember
that a selection happened in mouse down and issue the selection in mouse up
but only if a default selection has not happened. Since this would be
changing GTK platform behavior, I didn't attempt it.
- mouse click -> selection
- mouse click -> selection
- mouse double click -> default selection.

Bug.WithStack:
- run the ControlExample, go to the List tab - listen for Selection and Default Selection - double click an item in the example List on the page -> on gtk you'll get Selection - Selection - Default Selection -> on all other platforms you'll get Selection - Default Selection Probably true in Tree and Table as well. I tried to work around this once. GTK is actually issuing two events. The only way to fix this is to remember that a selection happened in mouse down and issue the selection in mouse up but only if a default selection has not happened. Since this would be changing GTK platform behavior, I didn't attempt it.
Need to verify that GTK is in fact doing this and it's not an obvious bug in SWT. I think GTK is doing it (there is no obvious bug in SWT in this part). Changing the selection to happen on mouse up instead of using gtk_changed is gonna cause trouble: the selection can be changed by keyboard input.
The problem is that GtkTreeView is using mouse down to implement the gtk_changed, so a double click consist: - mouse click -> selection - mouse click -> selection - mouse double click -> default selection.
we can try to detect we are in the second mouse click with " if ((event->button.time < (display->button_click_time[0] + display->double_click_time)) && (event->button.window == display->button_window[0]) && (event->button.button == display->button_number[0]) && (ABS (event->button.x - display->button_x[0]) <= display->double_click_distance) && (ABS (event->button.y - display->button_y[0]) <= display->double_click_distance))"
It means you must remember the time, the window, the button, and the x,y position for every button down in the toolkit.
Some other possible solution is to use gtk_change when the event type is keyboard and use mouse up to implement our own selection (as steve suggested). I think it is too hacky.
Any other ideas ?
Grant to prioirtize.
Bug.WithOutStack:
- run the ControlExample, go to the List tab - listen for Selection and Default Selection - double click an item in the example List on the page -> on gtk you'll get Selection - Selection - Default Selection -> on all other platforms you'll get Selection - Default Selection Probably true in Tree and Table as well. I tried to work around this once. GTK is actually issuing two events. The only way to fix this is to remember that a selection happened in mouse down and issue the selection in mouse up but only if a default selection has not happened. Since this would be changing GTK platform behavior, I didn't attempt it.
Need to verify that GTK is in fact doing this and it's not an obvious bug in SWT. I think GTK is doing it (there is no obvious bug in SWT in this part). Changing the selection to happen on mouse up instead of using gtk_changed is gonna cause trouble: the selection can be changed by keyboard input.
The problem is that GtkTreeView is using mouse down to implement the gtk_changed, so a double click consist: - mouse click -> selection - mouse click -> selection - mouse double click -> default selection.
we can try to detect we are in the second mouse click with " if ((event->button.time < (display->button_click_time[0] + display->double_click_time)) && (event->button.window == display->button_window[0]) && (event->button.button == display->button_number[0]) && (ABS (event->button.x - display->button_x[0]) <= display->double_click_distance) && (ABS (event->button.y - display->button_y[0]) <= display->double_click_distance))"
It means you must remember the time, the window, the button, and the x,y position for every button down in the toolkit.
Some other possible solution is to use gtk_change when the event type is keyboard and use mouse up to implement our own selection (as steve suggested). I think it is too hacky.
Any other ideas ?
Grant to prioirtize.

I have built a data structure of binary tree by constructing a new class of treenode containing an Object item and two treenode pointers.
Since I need to save this binary tree in a file, I use Serializable class of Java to do that.
The strange thing is that I can run the program properly under eclipse but if I invoke the debug mode and trace the program step by step, I've found that eclipse fail to finishing tracing the program because it throws IOException error when it read back the object from the file I have saved.
Do you need me to supply the source code for verification?
Rgds

Bug.Summery: Use a different method template for anonymous inner classes
Bug.WithStack:
Anonymous inner classes are Java's kludge to almost get closures, and the Java runtime libraries use them this way all over the place.
When I'm writing code that uses anonymous inner classes this way, I almost never want JavaDoc for either the class itself or for the method(s) inside the class.
Since the intention for a method created inside an anonymous inner class is different from the intention for a regular method, it would be nice if the template the generates a method inside an anonymous inner class were different.
Then the template could omit JavaDoc, but I could get my JavaDoc by default for regular methods. we should add a new options to enable/disable the generation of comment in annonymous classes not for 3.1 As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Anonymous inner classes are Java's kludge to almost get closures, and the Java runtime libraries use them this way all over the place.
When I'm writing code that uses anonymous inner classes this way, I almost never want JavaDoc for either the class itself or for the method(s) inside the class.
Since the intention for a method created inside an anonymous inner class is different from the intention for a regular method, it would be nice if the template the generates a method inside an anonymous inner class were different.
Then the template could omit JavaDoc, but I could get my JavaDoc by default for regular methods. we should add a new options to enable/disable the generation of comment in annonymous classes not for 3.1 As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Plugin manifest editor: retain context when switching from source to form tab

Lines.Line: - are on a form page
- switch to a source page
- change the selection on the source page
- switch back to the form page
... and expect the selection of the form page to remain constant.

Bug.WithStack:
I200411170800
It would be cool if the plugin manifest editor could retain the context when switching tabs. I.e. when I'm editing an Extension Element Detail on the "Extensions" tab and then switch to the plugin.xml tab, the selection should be in the xml element corresponding to the field I was editing just before (and vice versa).
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 61522 *** The way bug 61522 was solved, this is not a complete duplicate any more.
In 3.3M1, GUI selections are mapped to text selections on the source pages (only at the element level, not for individual attributes, but I can live with that).
But the other way 'round, this still does not work. I'm sometimes editing on a source tab and then decide that some Form UI would be more helpful to solve the task. Currently, I always have to search the element again after switching to the GUI pages, since neither the "selected" element nor the Outline selection are taken over.
Could you reopen this bug or shall I file a new one? You can reopen this one since the (vice versa) part was missed. Reopening and adjusting summary for remaining request. hey JLB, how much work is it to do the other direction? This may cause some unwanted behaviour for some users (that don't want their tree selections to be reset). Maybe we should have a toggle for this functionality, possibly as a button in the form toolbar. What do you think Markus? I'd vote against another toggle unless people really start asking for it. I don't see a clear use case where users ... - are on a form page - switch to a source page - change the selection on the source page - switch back to the form page ... and expect the selection of the form page to remain constant.
If they just switch to a source page, scroll around, and then go back, the selection should not be affected. If they are e.g. on the Extensions page and then switch to the MANIFEST.MF page, the selection on the Extensions page should also not be affected (there's nothing on the Extensions page to match the source selection, hence the form's selection should not be changed). Thanks for your input Markus.. I would however like to petition with the following as I believe it could be a common case.
When a user arrives at a source page (with the intent to inspect some xml) and a lot of text is selected, it would seem like a natural reaction to deselect the selection as inverted text is difficult to read. This would pose a problem of new elements being selected... it could be avoided if the user deselects within the element (but NOT within one of its children).
We could work around this feature by introducing a context menu action (on the source page) which would bring focus to the appropriate element (and even attribute field) on the extensions page.
Markus and Wassim, what are your thoughts? The "huge selection" is a bug in itself that I just didn't file so far (it's bug 154030 now;-). A "Show In" action would be better than nothing, but I still don't think it's necessary.
After all, the multi-page editor is just one editor, and having one selection shared across pages is the most natural behavior, IMO. Users who want two separate editors can always choose Window > New Editor. Janek, if we resolve bug 154030, we would address the valid issue you bring up in comment 8.
I was playing around with DreamWeaver today. When you switch between the raw html and the design page, the cursor does retain the context. However, they have an easier problem since they have no trees and no multipage editors.
However, I do believe that bug 154030 is the obstacle here to a reasonable solution to PDE. Thanks for the feedback, after closing bug 154030 this behaviour is definiltey worthwhile. Selections are now retained between the xml source page <-> Extensions/ExtensionPoints pages.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I200411170800
It would be cool if the plugin manifest editor could retain the context when switching tabs. I.e. when I'm editing an Extension Element Detail on the "Extensions" tab and then switch to the plugin.xml tab, the selection should be in the xml element corresponding to the field I was editing just before (and vice versa).

Bug.Summery: [PropertiesView] GEF implementation of PropertySheetEntry doesn't apply property changes for editors of type CheckboxCellEditor
Bug.WithStack:
org.eclipse.gef.internal.ui.properties.PropertySheetEntry doesn't apply property changes for org.eclipse.jface.viewers.CheckboxCellEditor, since the CheckboxCellEditor doesn't have a Control, and PropertySheetEntry.applyEditorValue() returns at line 120 if the editor's control is null.
This behaviour is not consistent with org.eclipse.ui.views.properties.PropertySheetEntry, which appears to work properly with CheckboxCellEditor. Defect found in 3.1M3 Randy, why was this moved to Platform-UI? David seems to be describing a problem in GEF's implementation of PropertySheetEntry. correct, this is a GEF-specific issue. He is referring to our copy of the jface class. JFace has the same bug. Anyway, we will subclassing the jface class soon so our copy of the bug is irrelevant. Please clarify, I'm not seeing the problem.
From the opening comment: "org.eclipse.ui.views.properties.PropertySheetEntry ... appears to work properly with CheckboxCellEditor."
Also, what do you mean by "the jface class"? The properties view is in org.eclipse.ui.views, not JFace.
To be clear: org.eclipse.ui.views.properties.PropertySheetEntry functions correctly, whereas org.eclipse.gef.internal.ui.properties.PropertySheetEntry does not. This is a GEF-specific defect that only occurs when a GEF selection is made and the property sheet is thusly populated with GEF-based PropertySheetEntry instances. My mistake, I suppose our copy is way out of sync with the one in eclipse.ui.views. It looks like we were doing a check to avoid multiple applications of the same value. This would go unnoticed in the platform, but in GEF causes two redundant commands to be executed.
So, the class that actually has the bug is being deleted soon. This means if we were working around something the workaround is going away too.
Sorry for the confusion. I'll open another bug if I see duplicate calls to applyEditorValue().
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 61413 *** Can I request that this defect remain open until it is indeed fixed? cancel that last request: presumably bug 61413 when addressed will resolve this issue.

org.eclipse.gef.internal.ui.properties.PropertySheetEntry doesn't apply property changes for org.eclipse.jface.viewers.CheckboxCellEditor, since the CheckboxCellEditor doesn't have a Control, and PropertySheetEntry.applyEditorValue() returns at line 120 if the editor's control is null.
This behaviour is not consistent with org.eclipse.ui.views.properties.PropertySheetEntry, which appears to work properly with CheckboxCellEditor. Defect found in 3.1M3 Randy, why was this moved to Platform-UI? David seems to be describing a problem in GEF's implementation of PropertySheetEntry. correct, this is a GEF-specific issue. He is referring to our copy of the jface class. JFace has the same bug. Anyway, we will subclassing the jface class soon so our copy of the bug is irrelevant. Please clarify, I'm not seeing the problem.
From the opening comment: "org.eclipse.ui.views.properties.PropertySheetEntry ... appears to work properly with CheckboxCellEditor."
Also, what do you mean by "the jface class"? The properties view is in org.eclipse.ui.views, not JFace.
To be clear: org.eclipse.ui.views.properties.PropertySheetEntry functions correctly, whereas org.eclipse.gef.internal.ui.properties.PropertySheetEntry does not. This is a GEF-specific defect that only occurs when a GEF selection is made and the property sheet is thusly populated with GEF-based PropertySheetEntry instances. My mistake, I suppose our copy is way out of sync with the one in eclipse.ui.views. It looks like we were doing a check to avoid multiple applications of the same value. This would go unnoticed in the platform, but in GEF causes two redundant commands to be executed.
So, the class that actually has the bug is being deleted soon. This means if we were working around something the workaround is going away too.
Sorry for the confusion. I'll open another bug if I see duplicate calls to applyEditorValue().

Bug.Summery: [consistency] Combo does not fire some KeyDowns

Lines.Line: - run the ControlExample, go to the Combo tab
- listen for KeyDown and KeyUp
- give focus to the example Combo on the page
- press Arrow-Down and Arrow-Up to go through the Combo's items and note that
no KeyDowns ever arrive, though the KeyUps do
To be decided with Steve if we should workaround this or not.
The Combo gets regular key events from the expected kEventTextInputUnicode
Arrows up and Down don't make it through kEventTextInputUnicode (the combo pops up the drow
down list and uses arrow down/up to switch selection). Arrows Left and right go through
kEventTextInputUnicode.

Bug.WithStack:
- run the ControlExample, go to the Combo tab - listen for KeyDown and KeyUp - give focus to the example Combo on the page - press Arrow-Down and Arrow-Up to go through the Combo's items and note that no KeyDowns ever arrive, though the KeyUps do To be decided with Steve if we should workaround this or not. The Combo gets regular key events from the expected kEventTextInputUnicode Arrows up and Down don't make it through kEventTextInputUnicode (the combo pops up the drow down list and uses arrow down/up to switch selection). Arrows Left and right go through kEventTextInputUnicode.
Working around it seems to require special code: in Combo.kEventRawkeyup, sendEvent KeyDown for arrow up and down. fixed v>20041124
Bug.WithOutStack:
- run the ControlExample, go to the Combo tab - listen for KeyDown and KeyUp - give focus to the example Combo on the page - press Arrow-Down and Arrow-Up to go through the Combo's items and note that no KeyDowns ever arrive, though the KeyUps do To be decided with Steve if we should workaround this or not. The Combo gets regular key events from the expected kEventTextInputUnicode Arrows up and Down don't make it through kEventTextInputUnicode (the combo pops up the drow down list and uses arrow down/up to switch selection). Arrows Left and right go through kEventTextInputUnicode.
Working around it seems to require special code: in Combo.kEventRawkeyup, sendEvent KeyDown for arrow up and down. fixed v>20041124

Bug.Summery: Restore corrupted workspace to a default working state

Lines.Line: 1. Function/Option to reset a workspace wrt meta-data for
base/core eclipse plug-ins to their default
values/settings (e.g. Search->File should show 4 tabs and
offer 5 "custom" choices) on startup or after startup.
This is to accommodate a workspace that has been corrupted.
This not to be confused with Perspective reset to default
values.
2. Extend 1. to be an api/capability available for all
plug-in developers
3. "1." should be extended to a validator for checking
workspace that have or may be corrupt, and offer the option
to re-set core meta-data/setting to the base default
settings
Moving to runtime. This seems to be an issue of the plugin registry being stale
or not properly reflecting the update (search dialog tabs are contributed via
extension point). I suspect the "-clean" argument in Eclipse 3.0 accomplishes
what is being asked for here.
Using the -clean command line argument has the effect you are looking for in
Eclipse 3.0 or greater. There is no plan to backport such functionality to
earlier releases. Please open a new bug report if you find a case where
metadata is still corrupt after starting with -clean.

Bug.WithStack:
In this scenario customer had applied and update against WSAD v512/Exclipse 2.1.3 and it resulted in some correuptiobn of the workspace in which the update was done. Specifically Search->File only showed 2 tabs and the Customize button only offerred those same choices....ther should be 5 choices.
The customer asked for this feature:
1. Function/Option to reset a workspace wrt meta-data for base/core eclipse plug-ins to their default values/settings (e.g. Search->File should show 4 tabs and offer 5 "custom" choices) on startup or after startup. This is to accommodate a workspace that has been corrupted. This not to be confused with Perspective reset to default values.
2. Extend 1. to be an api/capability available for all plug-in developers
3. "1." should be extended to a validator for checking workspace that have or may be corrupt, and offer the option to re-set core meta-data/setting to the base default settings Moving to runtime. This seems to be an issue of the plugin registry being stale or not properly reflecting the update (search dialog tabs are contributed via extension point). I suspect the "-clean" argument in Eclipse 3.0 accomplishes what is being asked for here. Using the -clean command line argument has the effect you are looking for in Eclipse 3.0 or greater. There is no plan to backport such functionality to earlier releases. Please open a new bug report if you find a case where metadata is still corrupt after starting with -clean.
Bug.WithOutStack:
In this scenario customer had applied and update against WSAD v512/Exclipse 2.1.3 and it resulted in some correuptiobn of the workspace in which the update was done. Specifically Search->File only showed 2 tabs and the Customize button only offerred those same choices....ther should be 5 choices.
The customer asked for this feature:
1. Function/Option to reset a workspace wrt meta-data for base/core eclipse plug-ins to their default values/settings (e.g. Search->File should show 4 tabs and offer 5 "custom" choices) on startup or after startup. This is to accommodate a workspace that has been corrupted. This not to be confused with Perspective reset to default values.
2. Extend 1. to be an api/capability available for all plug-in developers
3. "1." should be extended to a validator for checking workspace that have or may be corrupt, and offer the option to re-set core meta-data/setting to the base default settings Moving to runtime. This seems to be an issue of the plugin registry being stale or not properly reflecting the update (search dialog tabs are contributed via extension point). I suspect the "-clean" argument in Eclipse 3.0 accomplishes what is being asked for here. Using the -clean command line argument has the effect you are looking for in Eclipse 3.0 or greater. There is no plan to backport such functionality to earlier releases. Please open a new bug report if you find a case where metadata is still corrupt after starting with -clean.

Bug.Summery: Connection is broken during an update

Stacktrace.Reason: Software caused connection abort: socket write error

Lines.Line: - Eclipse3.0
- Java 1.4
- MS Windows 2000 as well as XP
- PC, 10/100MBit Ethernet
Another issue: we have switched to Eclipse3.0.1 & made some changes in our
code; now, it spent cca 1min with a verification of random plugin, let say
plugin-X: ping returns time less than 1ms, no interruption during pinging
arises, processor utilization: less than 1%, network utilization: less than 1% -
at both: at client as well as at server side; download of next plugin-Y fails
because of: java.net.SocketTimeoutException: Read timed out. Results from test
with local update site (directly from filesystem) using same build of an
application: it works well including no pause during the plugin-X verification.
Web Server:
Single Apache (2.0.52) used on local network, no proxy is used.
Note that update site contains 138 plugins.
Roman, what do you mean by "verification" ? Is it the string that you see in
the progress monitor ("Verifying blah blah...") ?
- description: problem during update leading to complete disconnection of a
client (when system can do that ??)
- occurrence: unknown (different networks, different clients)
- description: problem during installation of some plugin, download of the next
plugin fails with Read timed out.
- occurrence:
- it doesn't work with a client on Windows XP (2 stations tested)
- it doesn't work on platform SDK 3.0 as well as 3.0.1
- automatic update as well as update made by hand (feature-by-feature) doesn't
work
- local update site (file system) does work without any problem
- it doesn't work with Apache on Windows, it does work with Apache on Linux and
Tomcat on Windows (but: Software caused connection abort: socket write error;
Q: when such kind of error occurres ?)
- ping between client and server does work on 100% (without any break)
- tested on JVM 1.4 as well as 1.5
- tested on local network
- processor utilization: less than 1%, network utilization: less than 1%
On issue 2: if feasible, use the os and server (linux/apache) that works, or
causes the fewest problems

there you can see info produced by netstat tool I executed in different states of an update Created attachment 16125 an error dialog I can see when an update fails Thanks for the extra info, that should help. I'm worry about long ongoing in state FIN_WAIT_2 you can see in previous log as well.
So, it seems to me there is realy hard-core problem at low network level about connection finnalization.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 144876 *** I can also confirm this bug on Windows XP SP2 when performing auto updates using Eclipse SDK 3.2. The network stops working for at least one minute, sometimes longer.
Interesstingly, SSH sessions seem to survive as long as there is no actual traffic going on (dormant shell session).
After reading comment #25 (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=79212#c25) in this bug report, I tryed to diagnose something along these lines.
netstat showed, that Eclipse had 25 connections open to our web proxy, with the 25th remaining in SYNC state.
After disabling "Deterministic Network Enhancer" and "QoS Packet Scheduler" in the network connection's properties dialog, Eclipse was able to open at least 50 connections (probably as many as there were feature/plugin jars mentioned in the site.xml for timestamp checks or something) and everything worked like a charm.
I can't tell, which of the two services/protocols/drivers blocks connection attempts, as I didn't have the time to rule out one of them, but at least it works now. I already thought, I had a hardware failure, phuh....

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 144876 *** I can also confirm this bug on Windows XP SP2 when performing auto updates using Eclipse SDK 3.2. The network stops working for at least one minute, sometimes longer.
Interesstingly, SSH sessions seem to survive as long as there is no actual traffic going on (dormant shell session).
After reading comment #25 (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=79212#c25) in this bug report, I tryed to diagnose something along these lines.
netstat showed, that Eclipse had 25 connections open to our web proxy, with the 25th remaining in SYNC state.
After disabling "Deterministic Network Enhancer" and "QoS Packet Scheduler" in the network connection's properties dialog, Eclipse was able to open at least 50 connections (probably as many as there were feature/plugin jars mentioned in the site.xml for timestamp checks or something) and everything worked like a charm.
I can't tell, which of the two services/protocols/drivers blocks connection attempts, as I didn't have the time to rule out one of them, but at least it works now. I already thought, I had a hardware failure, phuh....

Bug.Summery: Support Mozilla on all platforms (if already installed)

Lines.Line: - check "Always use external browsers"
- check "Custom Browser"
- choose your favorite
The Windows Internet Explorer Browser Widged has the following disadvantages
compared to the Mozilla Widget under Linux:
- We're looking for a rich client platform to integrate our existing web based solutions and provide more user experience in our future products, so,
- We want a unique browser implementation through all platforms
- We want Java/Eclipse to interact with DOM to simulate user interaction on the web pages
- We also want Java/Eclipse to listen to DOM events to react to user input and monitor what's happening
- Have a full support for browser preferences
- We do not want the user to be forced to have a particular software on their computer other than Java (no Firefox/Mozilla installation is needed)
- Implement automated test case tools to test our web based solutions by simulating web user interaction with Java
- Cut down development costs with graphical design ( CSS, Javascript and co. does not have to care about IE but just follow standards )

- Focus on a particular version of the browser so we do not need to handle all differences between browsers (version of CSS or Javascript supported for example) and so reducing compatibility tests and development costs
- Extend the time between new browser versions so we can rely on a stable/choosen releases (so we are not dependent on a new IE release, a Windows update, custom installed browser...)
- use most of the technology provided by mozilla/firefox that IE can not handle (SVG, best XML/XSLT support...)

- force client side graphical issues by locking browser preferences towards our web based products so that browser extreme user configurations have no consequences on rendering and usage (so reducing maintenance and hotline)
- tightly integrate our new Rich Client products with existing web based applications by providing hot interaction between the browser and the rest of the application
- ship a package that we are known to work on every platform (Windows, Mac, Linux) without thinking about OS differences and OS installation related stuff
- have multiple Views in Eclipse based on a same opened session on a web application (nowadays, each view is another browser instance, so we can't share sessions for example, in a clean way)

Bug.WithStack:
Bug 41840 tells how to hack SWT for 2.1.1 to use Mozilla as browser widget on Windows. This PR requests that Mozilla becomes officially supported on Windows (or at least available via a commandline switch).
The instructions from bug 41840 don't work any more, since the files have been removed in HEAD.
Bug 71301 is related to this (requests that Mozilla is supported in Eclipse SDK). It would be really great to support mozilla (and/or firefox) in Eclipse. I'm really used to using "Find as you type", tabs, and other great fetures. Every time I start the Eclipse Help, I have to deal with the limited functionality of IE.
The Windows IE Browser widget and the Linux Mozilla one behave differently. For developing real multi platform application with SWT, Mozilla support for Windows would be really really interesting for us.
I think a Firefox binding would be even better than the existing Mozilla binding. See bug 72487 for Firefox request
Georgi: regarding tabs, are you referring to the possibility to bring up a popup menu when the user right clicks on a hyperlink, with the item "Open Link in new Tab" ? Georgi: a workaround for the Eclipse Help problem: Preferences > Help: - check "Always use external browsers" - check "Custom Browser" - choose your favorite The Windows Internet Explorer Browser Widged has the following disadvantages compared to the Mozilla Widget under Linux:
* it allows right mouse button context menu
* it always shows a grey border around the displayed HTML page (this makes it impossible to hide the fact that an application uses HTML internally); if you use two Browser widgets next to each other, you will get at least three pixels border between the two widgets
* it is possible to drop a "foreign file" to the widget - IE will try to open the dropped file - this is very bad if you're using HTML for designing parts of the GUI of your application
Janosch,
* simply disable the context Menu with calling browser.setMenu(new Menu(shell, SWT.NONE));
* the gray border may result from the SWT.BORDER stylebit, just call the constructor of the Browser widget with "SWT.NONE"
Regards, Ben Hi Ben,
* I could disable the context menu the way you described. Thank you very much.
* I am not able to remove the border of the IE browser widget. I'm now trying to draw it without any layout manager (using setBounds()) and I'm adding the browser widget with 'new Browser(parent, SWT.NONE)'.
Regards and thanks for your reply, Janosch * it is possible to drop a "foreign file" to the widget - IE will try to open the dropped file - this is very bad if you're using HTML for designing parts of the GUI of your application
This was fixed recently. This should not happen with a recent integration build. Janosh, if you still have problems with the border, please attach a screenshot. Try a recent integration build - the SWT.BORDER style to add/remove the IE 3D border was added sometimes in SWT 3.1. When using the current version of the MS IE Browser Widget under Windows, the following problems ARE SOLVED: * Right mouse button menu can be disabled by browser.setMenu(new Menu(shell, SWT.NONE)); * No border will be drawn for the browser widget if SWT.BORDER stylebit is not set * Drag and drop support is not working (which is good because it is often not wanted - see above)
=> About IE: This makes the SWT Browser Widget with IE under Windows much more usable.
=> About Mozilla-Support on Windows: I still want to vote for the Mozilla support because Mozilla is "free" and it is "multiplatform". To be able to use a Mozilla-based Browser widget under Linux and Windows would save development time because the rendering and JavaScript engine is (almost) equal then. Concurrent instances of Mozilla and IE embedded browsers should be supported on Windows. I don't know if this is the correct way to influence the development of a more robust Browser implementation in SWT or not. I suspect that I ought to be providing some formal enhancement request, but having reviewed the various postings concerning *some* of the issues, it is clear that you and the other people monitoring this forum are aware of and thinking about the issues. So, I would like to add a perspective.
Simply having the ability to embed a Mozilla- or Foxfire-based browser instance is not enough. Most of us are on the trail of 'the rich client' and that means integrating a lot of nice capability beyond the rendering of <html> pages. The very first level of integration requirement is that all the javascript that we have used to enhance those <html> pages has to communicate -- forwards and backwards -- with the SWT application. Granted the present <form> has limitations, but the drop-down boxes are there and the calls to our functions to modify a selection prior to a submit() are there. Sometimes we need to grab that selection in the SWT application and interceping the StatusText string and parsing name-value pairs is just plain wrong. We need a proper protocol for binding data from the embedded scripting language into our java code.
The second level of integration is that we really want to embedd <svg><script> in that <xhtml> page and now I need to be sure that I can communicate -- in both directions -- with those controls, those events and those functions. Forgetting SWT, today there is no cross-platform way to get the parent script engine to properly communicate with the embedded script engine. We want to activate a SWT button and have the action percolate all the way down to altering the animation behavior of the <circle> inside the <svg>. As nice as SWT's widgets look, I'm sorry, they are not what you can do with <svg> in terms of really energizing your current web applications.
I have been working on trying to solve the <svg> embedding so the absurdities of not having standards and protocols is fresh in my mind, but I really should be doing the same thing with <xforms> -- they are here now, you know. We really should be doing the same separation of model, view and control of our forms with this better solution, but it introduces the same problem. How do I populate <xform> content from my SWT application code; how do I retrieve <xform> content in my SWT application?
So, don't get me wrong; I wouldn't want to do anything to impede any progress towards improving on what you have given us with the current Browser. But, once or twice, your reply to a posting has been "... can you tell us what you want to do that for ..." So, what 'I want to do this stuff for' is that the ASP.NET Longhorn army is marching right down on our J2EE Servlets with answers to the question of how best to partition between client-side and server-side, how best to capitalize on the User Interface by enabling images, videos and audio to engage the end-user. The Mozilla army has infrastructure for doing most of the 'good things' that we need to do, but it is a lot more than simply tickling the rendering engine to get better looking stuff on the screen. I would like to see the SWT.Browser project address full-function, two-way data and control flow between the application and the 'contained browser'. > I don't know if this is the correct way to influence Feedback and use cases are always good. You can open a bugzilla report with the 'enhancement' flag. They always influence developers working in these components - even if we all understand each new feature has a specific implementation and maintainance cost attached to it and may not make it when these are considered versus the benefits. Another way if you have already invested massive amounts of work producing solid extensions to existing components is to contribute them to the Eclipse project.
So in your case, I'd recommend you open a separate bug report (just paste your comment) and provide details on the SVG and XForm cases. We can pursue from there. You can also mention there if you'd rather have specific IE/longhorn/.NET extensions to the Windows Browser implementation (a little bit like SWT OLE) and lose these features on Linux and the Mac, ie. in addition to the portable SWT Browser API, have specific extensions for IE/Mozilla/Safari - which would trade portability for functionality.
If/when you open the new PR, please paste its number here so that people interested here can follow up to the new PR. Thanks! I'm adding myself to the cc list because I was also looking for an option to use the mozilla/firefox/gecko browser widget under Windows. I have two reasons, first I just like some of the rendering and security benefits, and second (probably more importantly), I don't have convenient access to a Linux machine and would like to be able to easily switch back and forth for testing. For that second reason it "would be nice" that, if there was an option, it didn't require the workbench to be restarted when you change it. Also it "would be nice" if I could bind the switch to a key. I don't mind if I have to close and reopen any existing windows that use the browser widget.
I also am intrigued by the possiblities in comment #11 so if there is a new bugzilla opened to track that please post the number. > Simply having the ability to embed a Mozilla- or Foxfire-based browser instance > is not enough. Most of us are on the trail of 'the rich client' and that means > integrating a lot of nice capability beyond the rendering of <html> pages. ... > in that <xhtml> page and now I need to be sure that I can communicate -- in > both directions -- with those controls, those events and those functions. > Forgetting SWT, today there is no cross-platform way to get the parent script > engine to properly communicate with the embedded script engine.
Yes, Yes, Yes!! I've been searching for months for the proper solution to use as a "Rich Client". I've bounced back and forth between what I WANTED to do initially (SVG + XForms), to straight web apps, and I think I've finally settled on giving Eclipse RCP a go. Using the browser widget will get me back to some of the simple form rendering I wanted to do, but the idea of using Mozilla, with its support for XUL, soon to come SVG, etc. might open the door back up for some really interesting rich clients. Having part of the client be SWT when custom code is warranted, but many other aspects of the client be simply "open up a browser window, and get an interface rendered by the server using [put your favorite XML based technology here]" would make for quite the robust app. I've added myself to the cc list also. As I progress further with this experiment, I may find myself joining in to make this happen.
*** Bug 83065 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** See bug 58360. The last attachment there is an Eclipse fragment for org.eclpse.swt that provides a MozillaBrowser widget for Windows. It is based on the Eclipse 3.0.2 version of the gtk Browser widget. It works only with Mozilla 1.4.x. Is this a dup of bug 58360? Or vice-versa? *** Bug 58360 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 120422 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** By definition, the Browser widget of SWT is the native browser widget for the platform. For example, on Windows it is IE. So, I am converting this request into one for a new widget based only on Mozilla.
Probably the best design would be to have a minimal SWT Mozilla binding control, allowing clients to then speak directly to a generic XPCOM Java binding.
Note that this would be dependent on a XULRunner or other embeddable Mozilla installed on each platform. Firefox as shipped from mozilla.org is statically linked and not usable for embedding. I fully support this. As long as the binding is done in such a way that it would allow much greater control than the current SWT Browser widget.
The main features I'd like to see would be: * Full control over browser content. Including access to browser DOM tree and event model. * Full control over browser internals (preferences, extensions, window spawning/blocking, coockie handling, etc.)
It might not come all at once but the separate support for Mozilla component would *only* make sense if it would provide more features and control than a native browser component support.
Having the same rendering engine for all platforms would ease cross-platform portability for html-based RCP applications. Note that Bug 120422 is not a dup of this bug and that has been corrected:
- Bug 79213 (this bug) would require the user to have Mozilla (or possibly Firefox) already installed in order to access it.
- Bug 120422 would ship enough of Mozilla/Firefox in a plug-in so the user would not have to install anything else. Ed, why push this point if there isn't even an implementation yet for all platforms? Sorry, I didn't mean to be pushy. I just want to make sure people are clear on what the bugzilla entries mean so there won't be a repeat of what happened to bug 72487 . Created attachment 32773 Mozilla SWT fragment
This should be a good starting point for you guys. This is an SWT fragment project that embeds Mozilla in an SWT widget.
* Code is based on existing SWT/Linux Mozilla code, and the old SWT/Win32 Mozilla code, before it was removed. It's based on an older version, so missing many changes that went into CVS towards the end of 2005. * Makes use of JavaXPCOM component (http://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/JavaXPCOM) and XULRunner (http://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/XULRunner). XULRunner is the new "GRE" for Mozilla, and registers itself with the platform. JavaXPCOM is a Java API for Mozilla, which makes the embedding code much cleaner, and gets rid of JNI code in the embedding code. * Right now, supports Linux and Win32; haven't had time to work on Mac OS X. * Platform specific code is split into separate files, so you need to copy the appropriate ".classpath_XXX" file to ".classpath". If anyone can think of a better way to do this, please let me know.
I wrote the JavaXPCOM code, so if you have suggestions, please let me know.
I don't work with SWT or Eclipse code often, so it would be best if someone here who is more knowledgable could take this code and start working with it. I'd be happy to help out with the JavaXPCOM and Mozilla interactions. I'd like to get this to work and can help you with the Eclipse-side stuff.
It would be very helpful for me if I could just get some jars from you that contain whatever else I need from the Mozilla projects. As mentioned previously, this code depends on XULRunner and its JavaXPCOM component. The XULRunner releases can be found here: ftp://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/xulrunner/releases/1.8.0.1. This needs to be installed according to the release notes (http://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/XULRunner_1.8.0.1_Release_Notes). You will then need to add the MozillaInterfaces.jar file to your build path; this jar is available in the xulrunner/sdk/lib directory. If you prefer, the jar is available as a plugin here: ftp://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/xulrunner/releases/1.8.0.1/eclipse/org.mozilla.xpcom_1.8.0.1.jar. How is the Ajax toolkit going to handle this? Supposedly it will come with "an embedded Mozilla web browser" (http://www.eclipse.org/proposals/atf/). The AJAX Toolkit Framework is currently using this code to embed Mozilla on Win32 and Linux. But that project isn't the correct place for this code; it should be its own project. OK Javier, it looks like I've got this to work. After installing the plugins and installing and registering XULRunner, I am able to create an SWT shell, embed a MozillaBrowser in it, and navigate to a URL.
I'd like to try to use tabs, and I was hoping that there would be a simple interface for me to use them. But is that something I should be doing by writing some XUL? No, tabs are a "front end" construct, and as such, the MozillaBrowser class would need to be extended to support tabs. (In reply to comment #26)

Our compagny would like to have a Browser plugin based on Firefox or Gecko. And we'll work on it. Help is welcome ! The reasons follows : - We're looking for a rich client platform to integrate our existing web based solutions and provide more user experience in our future products, so, - We want a unique browser implementation through all platforms - We want Java/Eclipse to interact with DOM to simulate user interaction on the web pages - We also want Java/Eclipse to listen to DOM events to react to user input and monitor what's happening - Have a full support for browser preferences - We do not want the user to be forced to have a particular software on their computer other than Java (no Firefox/Mozilla installation is needed)
Thus we should provide a way to do the following : - Implement automated test case tools to test our web based solutions by simulating web user interaction with Java - Cut down development costs with graphical design ( CSS, Javascript and co. does not have to care about IE but just follow standards ) - Focus on a particular version of the browser so we do not need to handle all differences between browsers (version of CSS or Javascript supported for example) and so reducing compatibility tests and development costs - Extend the time between new browser versions so we can rely on a stable/choosen releases (so we are not dependent on a new IE release, a Windows update, custom installed browser...) - use most of the technology provided by mozilla/firefox that IE can not handle (SVG, best XML/XSLT support...) - force client side graphical issues by locking browser preferences towards our web based products so that browser extreme user configurations have no consequences on rendering and usage (so reducing maintenance and hotline) - tightly integrate our new Rich Client products with existing web based applications by providing hot interaction between the browser and the rest of the application - ship a package that we are known to work on every platform (Windows, Mac, Linux) without thinking about OS differences and OS installation related stuff - have multiple Views in Eclipse based on a same opened session on a web application (nowadays, each view is another browser instance, so we can't share sessions for example, in a clean way)
Hope that'll help to understand our motivations and give you an idea of what an embbeded browser component can provide (more that displaying web pages).
Help is needed for this. Hope some of you will understand. Please contribute to this discussion, and forgive me for my so bad english ! As a follow-up to comment 36, and all of the other requests for this, this is something that SWT is planning for the 3.3 timeframe.

*** Bug 57477 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** The first part of this work is released, the Mozilla GRE can now be used to render Browser contents on win32 and OS X if a XULRunner is installed and registered on the machine. To specify that this should be used just create your Browser with style SWT.MOZILLA.
Note that there are some specific version requirements to run this on OS X that do not apply to windows or linux:
- on OS X your jre must be "Java for Mac OS X 10.4, Release 5 Developer Preview 2", which is available on Apple Developer Connection ( http://connect.apple.com/ ) (registration is free)
- on OS X your XULRunner must currently be a 1.9 stream build, such as http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/xulrunner/nightly/latest-trunk/xulrunner-1.9a2pre.en-US.mac-pkg.dmg -> note that a future 1.8.x stream build of XULRunner may have support for this on OS X; if this build becomes available then a comment will be added here with a link to it
- on windows and linux you can use any jre and XULRunner version
We are actively investigating bug 162942 which prevents focus from being given to a text field by clicking on it. The user workaround for now is to tab into the text field.
The second part of this work (binding JavaXPCOM to a Browser instance) is logged as bug 173117.

Georgi: regarding tabs, are you referring to the possibility to bring up a popup menu when the user right clicks on a hyperlink, with the item "Open Link in new Tab" ? Georgi: a workaround for the Eclipse Help problem: Preferences > Help: - check "Always use external browsers" - check "Custom Browser" - choose your favorite The Windows Internet Explorer Browser Widged has the following disadvantages compared to the Mozilla Widget under Linux:
* it allows right mouse button context menu
* it always shows a grey border around the displayed HTML page (this makes it impossible to hide the fact that an application uses HTML internally); if you use two Browser widgets next to each other, you will get at least three pixels border between the two widgets
* it is possible to drop a "foreign file" to the widget - IE will try to open the dropped file - this is very bad if you're using HTML for designing parts of the GUI of your application
Janosch,
* simply disable the context Menu with calling browser.setMenu(new Menu(shell, SWT.NONE));
* the gray border may result from the SWT.BORDER stylebit, just call the constructor of the Browser widget with "SWT.NONE"
Regards, Ben Hi Ben,
* I could disable the context menu the way you described. Thank you very much.
* I am not able to remove the border of the IE browser widget. I'm now trying to draw it without any layout manager (using setBounds()) and I'm adding the browser widget with 'new Browser(parent, SWT.NONE)'.
Regards and thanks for your reply, Janosch * it is possible to drop a "foreign file" to the widget - IE will try to open the dropped file - this is very bad if you're using HTML for designing parts of the GUI of your application
This was fixed recently. This should not happen with a recent integration build. Janosh, if you still have problems with the border, please attach a screenshot. Try a recent integration build - the SWT.BORDER style to add/remove the IE 3D border was added sometimes in SWT 3.1. When using the current version of the MS IE Browser Widget under Windows, the following problems ARE SOLVED: * Right mouse button menu can be disabled by browser.setMenu(new Menu(shell, SWT.NONE)); * No border will be drawn for the browser widget if SWT.BORDER stylebit is not set * Drag and drop support is not working (which is good because it is often not wanted - see above)
=> About IE: This makes the SWT Browser Widget with IE under Windows much more usable.
=> About Mozilla-Support on Windows: I still want to vote for the Mozilla support because Mozilla is "free" and it is "multiplatform". To be able to use a Mozilla-based Browser widget under Linux and Windows would save development time because the rendering and JavaScript engine is (almost) equal then. Concurrent instances of Mozilla and IE embedded browsers should be supported on Windows. I don't know if this is the correct way to influence the development of a more robust Browser implementation in SWT or not. I suspect that I ought to be providing some formal enhancement request, but having reviewed the various postings concerning *some* of the issues, it is clear that you and the other people monitoring this forum are aware of and thinking about the issues. So, I would like to add a perspective.
Simply having the ability to embed a Mozilla- or Foxfire-based browser instance is not enough. Most of us are on the trail of 'the rich client' and that means integrating a lot of nice capability beyond the rendering of <html> pages. The very first level of integration requirement is that all the javascript that we have used to enhance those <html> pages has to communicate -- forwards and backwards -- with the SWT application. Granted the present <form> has limitations, but the drop-down boxes are there and the calls to our functions to modify a selection prior to a submit() are there. Sometimes we need to grab that selection in the SWT application and interceping the StatusText string and parsing name-value pairs is just plain wrong. We need a proper protocol for binding data from the embedded scripting language into our java code.
The second level of integration is that we really want to embedd <svg><script> in that <xhtml> page and now I need to be sure that I can communicate -- in both directions -- with those controls, those events and those functions. Forgetting SWT, today there is no cross-platform way to get the parent script engine to properly communicate with the embedded script engine. We want to activate a SWT button and have the action percolate all the way down to altering the animation behavior of the <circle> inside the <svg>. As nice as SWT's widgets look, I'm sorry, they are not what you can do with <svg> in terms of really energizing your current web applications.
I have been working on trying to solve the <svg> embedding so the absurdities of not having standards and protocols is fresh in my mind, but I really should be doing the same thing with <xforms> -- they are here now, you know. We really should be doing the same separation of model, view and control of our forms with this better solution, but it introduces the same problem. How do I populate <xform> content from my SWT application code; how do I retrieve <xform> content in my SWT application?
So, don't get me wrong; I wouldn't want to do anything to impede any progress towards improving on what you have given us with the current Browser. But, once or twice, your reply to a posting has been "... can you tell us what you want to do that for ..." So, what 'I want to do this stuff for' is that the ASP.NET Longhorn army is marching right down on our J2EE Servlets with answers to the question of how best to partition between client-side and server-side, how best to capitalize on the User Interface by enabling images, videos and audio to engage the end-user. The Mozilla army has infrastructure for doing most of the 'good things' that we need to do, but it is a lot more than simply tickling the rendering engine to get better looking stuff on the screen. I would like to see the SWT.Browser project address full-function, two-way data and control flow between the application and the 'contained browser'. > I don't know if this is the correct way to influence Feedback and use cases are always good. You can open a bugzilla report with the 'enhancement' flag. They always influence developers working in these components - even if we all understand each new feature has a specific implementation and maintainance cost attached to it and may not make it when these are considered versus the benefits. Another way if you have already invested massive amounts of work producing solid extensions to existing components is to contribute them to the Eclipse project.
So in your case, I'd recommend you open a separate bug report (just paste your comment) and provide details on the SVG and XForm cases. We can pursue from there. You can also mention there if you'd rather have specific IE/longhorn/.NET extensions to the Windows Browser implementation (a little bit like SWT OLE) and lose these features on Linux and the Mac, ie. in addition to the portable SWT Browser API, have specific extensions for IE/Mozilla/Safari - which would trade portability for functionality.
If/when you open the new PR, please paste its number here so that people interested here can follow up to the new PR. Thanks! I'm adding myself to the cc list because I was also looking for an option to use the mozilla/firefox/gecko browser widget under Windows. I have two reasons, first I just like some of the rendering and security benefits, and second (probably more importantly), I don't have convenient access to a Linux machine and would like to be able to easily switch back and forth for testing. For that second reason it "would be nice" that, if there was an option, it didn't require the workbench to be restarted when you change it. Also it "would be nice" if I could bind the switch to a key. I don't mind if I have to close and reopen any existing windows that use the browser widget.
I also am intrigued by the possiblities in comment #11 so if there is a new bugzilla opened to track that please post the number. > Simply having the ability to embed a Mozilla- or Foxfire-based browser instance > is not enough. Most of us are on the trail of 'the rich client' and that means > integrating a lot of nice capability beyond the rendering of <html> pages. ... > in that <xhtml> page and now I need to be sure that I can communicate -- in > both directions -- with those controls, those events and those functions. > Forgetting SWT, today there is no cross-platform way to get the parent script > engine to properly communicate with the embedded script engine.
Yes, Yes, Yes!! I've been searching for months for the proper solution to use as a "Rich Client". I've bounced back and forth between what I WANTED to do initially (SVG + XForms), to straight web apps, and I think I've finally settled on giving Eclipse RCP a go. Using the browser widget will get me back to some of the simple form rendering I wanted to do, but the idea of using Mozilla, with its support for XUL, soon to come SVG, etc. might open the door back up for some really interesting rich clients. Having part of the client be SWT when custom code is warranted, but many other aspects of the client be simply "open up a browser window, and get an interface rendered by the server using [put your favorite XML based technology here]" would make for quite the robust app. I've added myself to the cc list also. As I progress further with this experiment, I may find myself joining in to make this happen.
*** Bug 83065 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** See bug 58360. The last attachment there is an Eclipse fragment for org.eclpse.swt that provides a MozillaBrowser widget for Windows. It is based on the Eclipse 3.0.2 version of the gtk Browser widget. It works only with Mozilla 1.4.x. Is this a dup of bug 58360? Or vice-versa? *** Bug 58360 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 120422 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** By definition, the Browser widget of SWT is the native browser widget for the platform. For example, on Windows it is IE. So, I am converting this request into one for a new widget based only on Mozilla.
Probably the best design would be to have a minimal SWT Mozilla binding control, allowing clients to then speak directly to a generic XPCOM Java binding.
Note that this would be dependent on a XULRunner or other embeddable Mozilla installed on each platform. Firefox as shipped from mozilla.org is statically linked and not usable for embedding. I fully support this. As long as the binding is done in such a way that it would allow much greater control than the current SWT Browser widget.
The main features I'd like to see would be: * Full control over browser content. Including access to browser DOM tree and event model. * Full control over browser internals (preferences, extensions, window spawning/blocking, coockie handling, etc.)
It might not come all at once but the separate support for Mozilla component would *only* make sense if it would provide more features and control than a native browser component support.
Having the same rendering engine for all platforms would ease cross-platform portability for html-based RCP applications. Note that Bug 120422 is not a dup of this bug and that has been corrected:
- Bug 79213 (this bug) would require the user to have Mozilla (or possibly Firefox) already installed in order to access it.
- Bug 120422 would ship enough of Mozilla/Firefox in a plug-in so the user would not have to install anything else. Ed, why push this point if there isn't even an implementation yet for all platforms? Sorry, I didn't mean to be pushy. I just want to make sure people are clear on what the bugzilla entries mean so there won't be a repeat of what happened to bug 72487 . Created attachment 32773 Mozilla SWT fragment
This should be a good starting point for you guys. This is an SWT fragment project that embeds Mozilla in an SWT widget.
* Code is based on existing SWT/Linux Mozilla code, and the old SWT/Win32 Mozilla code, before it was removed. It's based on an older version, so missing many changes that went into CVS towards the end of 2005. * Makes use of JavaXPCOM component (http://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/JavaXPCOM) and XULRunner (http://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/XULRunner). XULRunner is the new "GRE" for Mozilla, and registers itself with the platform. JavaXPCOM is a Java API for Mozilla, which makes the embedding code much cleaner, and gets rid of JNI code in the embedding code. * Right now, supports Linux and Win32; haven't had time to work on Mac OS X. * Platform specific code is split into separate files, so you need to copy the appropriate ".classpath_XXX" file to ".classpath". If anyone can think of a better way to do this, please let me know.
I wrote the JavaXPCOM code, so if you have suggestions, please let me know.
I don't work with SWT or Eclipse code often, so it would be best if someone here who is more knowledgable could take this code and start working with it. I'd be happy to help out with the JavaXPCOM and Mozilla interactions. I'd like to get this to work and can help you with the Eclipse-side stuff.
It would be very helpful for me if I could just get some jars from you that contain whatever else I need from the Mozilla projects. As mentioned previously, this code depends on XULRunner and its JavaXPCOM component. The XULRunner releases can be found here: ftp://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/xulrunner/releases/1.8.0.1. This needs to be installed according to the release notes (http://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/XULRunner_1.8.0.1_Release_Notes). You will then need to add the MozillaInterfaces.jar file to your build path; this jar is available in the xulrunner/sdk/lib directory. If you prefer, the jar is available as a plugin here: ftp://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/xulrunner/releases/1.8.0.1/eclipse/org.mozilla.xpcom_1.8.0.1.jar. How is the Ajax toolkit going to handle this? Supposedly it will come with "an embedded Mozilla web browser" (http://www.eclipse.org/proposals/atf/). The AJAX Toolkit Framework is currently using this code to embed Mozilla on Win32 and Linux. But that project isn't the correct place for this code; it should be its own project. OK Javier, it looks like I've got this to work. After installing the plugins and installing and registering XULRunner, I am able to create an SWT shell, embed a MozillaBrowser in it, and navigate to a URL.
I'd like to try to use tabs, and I was hoping that there would be a simple interface for me to use them. But is that something I should be doing by writing some XUL? No, tabs are a "front end" construct, and as such, the MozillaBrowser class would need to be extended to support tabs. (In reply to comment #26)

- on OS X your XULRunner must currently be a 1.9 stream build, such as http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/xulrunner/nightly/latest-trunk/xulrunner-1.9a2pre.en-US.mac-pkg.dmg -> note that a future 1.8.x stream build of XULRunner may have support for this on OS X; if this build becomes available then a comment will be added here with a link to it
- on windows and linux you can use any jre and XULRunner version
We are actively investigating bug 162942 which prevents focus from being given to a text field by clicking on it. The user workaround for now is to tab into the text field.
The second part of this work (binding JavaXPCOM to a Browser instance) is logged as bug 173117.
Shouldn't General / Web Browser preference page allow to choose between IE and Mozilla as an internal web browser? sure, I've logged bug 173128
*** Bug 78048 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** If you're on Linux/GTK and seeing the browser take excessive memory with M5, see bug 173782 for comments on the problem and a work-around. I forgot to update this report, OSX users no longer need to use a 1.9 stream build of xulrunner, they can use xulrunner 1.8.1.3 (this is a real release). It's available at http://releases.mozilla.org/pub/mozilla.org/xulrunner/releases/1.8.1.3/contrib/

Bug.Summery: When having two workbenches open, an attached agent in one, will show up in the attach wizard in the other

Lines.Line: 1. Open two workbenches running at the same time.
2. Attach to an agent in one of the workbenches.
3. Go to the attach wizard in the other workbench, the agent shows up, but
should not.

Bug.WithStack:
1. Open two workbenches running at the same time. 2. Attach to an agent in one of the workbenches. 3. Go to the attach wizard in the other workbench, the agent shows up, but should not.
The agent does not show up if we go to the attach wizard in the same workbench where we attached to the agent.
I also tested this with an older Hyades driver (20040830_2107). I saw the same issue. This is causing crashing in higher products when two users attempt to monitor the same agent. This is a must-fix.
One question, can you go ahead to attach to the agent inside the 2nd workbench? It should throw back an exception saying that it is already attached and the workbnech is properly handling the exception (except that it should not show the "Attached" icon in the Profiling Monitor view. it should show the "Detached" icon instead). The listAgents() call by design is to show all agents, both attached or detached ones. I remember this behaviour. I was not actually able to attach to an allready attached agent. The problem was with the agent being visible, to be selected, to attempt an attach. Terry, since this duo-attach scenario is being correctly handled by the RAC/workbench (you can't attach from the 2nd workbench since an exception was thrown) I will return this as "working as designed".
Since you can't attach twice, you will not be able to start monioring from both workbenches as described by Curtis. I hope the workbench side should not allow the "start monitoring" operation when an agent is not attached. My earlier post was a little misleading. Currently it does let you attach two workbenches to the same user, but it *shouldn't*. The query to the agent to see if it was attached or not (isAttached() ?) was returning false, while it was actually true. So the workbench has no way to know whether it should let the user attach or not. The AgentImpl.isAttach() will return a local copy of the isAttached flag. Please use the AgentImpl.isAttached(boolean remote) to perform a remote query of the isAttached status. So you can call AgentImpl.isAttached(true) to get the most up-to-date status of the agent. For legacy support, we cannot change the null arg isAttach() method to use the remote query. Please investigate, Terry. Terry, if the workaround specified by Terry fixes the problem please go ahead and implement it. After that move the defect back to Samson. The problem is still valid and needs to be addressed by the agent controller layer Fix submitted. please attach the patch to its corresponding 3.0.2 bug 79568 Created attachment 16464 patch *** Bug 79568 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Verified: Build 3.0_20041217_1348 As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

1. Open two workbenches running at the same time. 2. Attach to an agent in one of the workbenches. 3. Go to the attach wizard in the other workbench, the agent shows up, but should not.
The agent does not show up if we go to the attach wizard in the same workbench where we attached to the agent.
I also tested this with an older Hyades driver (20040830_2107). I saw the same issue. This is causing crashing in higher products when two users attempt to monitor the same agent. This is a must-fix.

Bug.Summery: [IDE][Markers] Feature request to filter tasks from "derived" resources
Bug.WithStack:
There should be an option in the "Filters" dialog to filter out resources marked as "derived". I believe this can be done with the IResource method isDerived(). moving to Stefan as it is Filter and marker related. Filters can be applied in more than one place. I guess the submitter of this bug is thinking of the resource navigator? Another place where this filter would make a lot of sense is the "Problems" view. An example:
JavaCC generated output will contain a lot of warnings such as "Statement unnecessarily nested with else clause" etc. This clobber the view so that significant warnings is harder to see. We are also looking at better categorization which should make this easier. There are no plans to work on this as categorization will solve the problem more generally

Bug.Summery: Provide UI to add/remove natures
Bug.WithStack:
While there is a UI to edit the builders on a project, there is not a UI that I can find to modify the natures assigned to a project.
As a result, most plugins that use natures tack an action on to IProject's popup menu to add a specific type of nature.
It would be good in my opinion to have a page on the property page of a project that allows the user to modify the natures assigned to a project.
Apologies in advance if this a dupe; I did look for similar bugs.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 36959 ***

Bug.Summery: Allow user to assign different address/port for HTTP and HTTPS proxies
Bug.WithStack: We need to allow the user to assign different addresses/ports for HTTP and HTTPS proxies. Today, we make sure that both HTTP and HTTPS proxies are the same. If they are different, we display an error message and do not allow the recording to commence. Upon approval for 3.0.2 in 11/29 Hyades committer meeting, I've assigned to Mark Dunn. Made modifications to allow a user to specify (through IE configuration settings) that HTTP traffic should go to one HTTP proxy server, and that secure (HTTPS) traffic should go through a different proxy server. Found a bug during validation testing. Must check for null in RecorderRegistryInfo.java in case running with NONE as browser preference. Found solution to problem when NONE is default browser. Must check for null on the RecorderRegistryInfo object. Found a bug injected during this enhancement in that the connection to the proxy server handling SSL commands did not work correctly. Found problem injected during this enhancement and fixed it. Bug.Summery: [JFace] org.eclipse.jface.preference.PreferencePage.setMessage() should use an ellipsis for long names.
Bug.WithStack:
org.eclipse.jface.preference.PreferencePage.setMessage() does not seem to wrap the message if the message is long. If you resize the preference window, you can see the whole message. But it would be nice to see the whole message without the need to resize it.
From what I have seen, this happens when you call setMessage() to change the message from a short/blank one to a long one. This is by design so as not to force a resize of the preference page due to an over long message. We saw this problem during globalization. The message is very short in English, but after translated into different languages, the message became longer. We have seen this problem with 6 languages out of 9. Also, some Asian characters are much wider than Latin characters. Eclipse should make the effort to hold longer/wider messages in preference page. It is easy to maintain a short English message, but it is very hard to control the length after translated into other languages. This is a general issue with anything translated. The only possible compromise is to shorten the message with an ellipsis if it is going to be truncated.
Message suppliers and translators should be aware of this issue and should endeavour to not create over long messages.
Be aware that the message is intended to indicate an error in a field in the dialog so it should be short and clear anyways. Closing the bug... Closing...

This is by design so as not to force a resize of the preference page due to an over long message. We saw this problem during globalization. The message is very short in English, but after translated into different languages, the message became longer. We have seen this problem with 6 languages out of 9. Also, some Asian characters are much wider than Latin characters. Eclipse should make the effort to hold longer/wider messages in preference page. It is easy to maintain a short English message, but it is very hard to control the length after translated into other languages. This is a general issue with anything translated. The only possible compromise is to shorten the message with an ellipsis if it is going to be truncated.
Message suppliers and translators should be aware of this issue and should endeavour to not create over long messages.
Be aware that the message is intended to indicate an error in a field in the dialog so it should be short and clear anyways. Closing the bug... Closing...
